shredder 0.1.0

Working With brms

Source: vignettes/brms.Rmd
brms.Rmd
library(shredder)
library(brms)

Generate Data

group <- rep(c("treat", "placebo"), 
             each = 30)

symptom_post <- c(
  rnorm(30, mean = 1, sd = 2), 
  rnorm(30, mean = 0, sd = 1)
)

dat1 <- data.frame(group, symptom_post)

Run Model

fit <- brm(bf(symptom_post ~ group, sigma ~ group), 
           data = dat1, 
           family = gaussian())
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 4000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.01027   0.20784 -0.40440  0.42267       4527 1.00004
sigma_Intercept   0.11407   0.13393 -0.12910  0.39634       3262 1.00097
grouptreat        1.28662   0.49748  0.30889  2.28151       2933 1.00162
sigma_grouptreat  0.77164   0.18749  0.39934  1.14317       3272 1.00084

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Select first 100 Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_slice <- fit%>%stan_slice(1:100)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1100; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 400

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.01027   0.18592 -0.36801  0.38544        440 0.99761
sigma_Intercept   0.10454   0.12931 -0.12454  0.34959        377 0.99532
grouptreat        1.27984   0.47398  0.42062  2.11409        357 1.01209
sigma_grouptreat  0.77950   0.17700  0.44493  1.14552        344 0.99818

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_slice%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Sample 25% of Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_sample <- fit%>%
  stan_sample_frac(0.25)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1250; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 1000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept         0.01096   0.20496 -0.39277  0.42267        970 1.00205
sigma_Intercept   0.11702   0.13273 -0.11963  0.41012        949 1.00616
grouptreat        1.28237   0.49328  0.32380  2.23726       1008 0.99896
sigma_grouptreat  0.76845   0.19156  0.37881  1.14457        949 1.00227

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_sample%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional

fit_filter <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1064; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 256

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept        -0.16357   0.19304 -0.56105  0.19018        215 1.00059
sigma_Intercept   0.12529   0.13731 -0.14270  0.40252        207 1.00542
grouptreat        2.24700   0.20834  2.01055  2.82100        178 0.99881
sigma_grouptreat  0.80708   0.19791  0.41101  1.17686        232 0.99078

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional Subset Chain

fit_filter_chain <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)%>%
  stan_retain(chains = 1)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 1 chains, each with iter = 1064; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 64

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept        -0.14177   0.18906 -0.55238  0.21160         52 1.01743
sigma_Intercept   0.10701   0.12342 -0.12401  0.33862         54 0.98556
grouptreat        2.21724   0.17174  2.02460  2.62651         49 0.98789
sigma_grouptreat  0.82247   0.17687  0.50765  1.14057         46 0.98425

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter_chain%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)
